title: How to Dial a Rotary Phone

steps.title: Remove the handset from the cradle.
steps.content: Remove the handset from the cradle.

steps.title: Place the handset to your ear and listen for a dial tone.
steps.content: Place the handset to your ear and listen for a dial tone. The dial tone should be a mid-ranged, constant pitch. If you do not hear a dial tone, something is wrong. 3 Ways to Diagnose Landline Phone Problems

steps.title: Place your finger on the first number you wish to dial.
steps.content: Place your finger on the first number you wish to dial. Each number has a corresponding hole that will allow you to place your finger in to begin dialing that number.

steps.title: Rotate the dial clockwise until your finger touches the finger stop.
steps.content: Rotate the dial clockwise until your finger touches the finger stop. The finger stop is a shaped piece of metal passing over the dial. Your finger should not be able to pass through it.

steps.title: Remove your finger from the hole.
steps.content: Remove your finger from the hole. This will allow the dial to return to its original position.

steps.title: Find your second number and repeat steps three through five.
steps.content: Find your second number and repeat steps three through five. Do this for the remaining numbers. After all the numbers are dialed, the call should automatically connect.

steps.title: Return the phone to the cradle when you are finished with your conversation.
steps.content: Return the phone to the cradle when you are finished with your conversation.

steps.title: Remove the handset from the cradle.
steps.content: Remove the handset from the cradle.

steps.title: Listen for a dial tone.
steps.content: Listen for a dial tone. The dial tone should be a mid-ranged, constant pitch. If you do not hear a dial tone, something is wrong. 3 Ways to Diagnose Landline Phone Problems

steps.title: Hold the handset with the dial up.
steps.content: Hold the handset with the dial up. The dial is located between the earpiece and mouthpiece of the phone.

steps.title: Place your finger on the first number you wish to dial.
steps.content: Place your finger on the first number you wish to dial. Each number has a corresponding hole that will allow you to place your finger in to begin dialing that number.

steps.title: Rotate the dial clockwise.
steps.content: Rotate the dial clockwise. Push through the metal stop until both the metal stop and the dial no longer move.

steps.title: Remove your finger from the opening.
steps.content: Remove your finger from the opening. This will allow the dial and the metal stop to return to their original positions.

steps.title: Find your second number and repeat steps four through six.
steps.content: Find your second number and repeat steps four through six. Do this for the remaining numbers.

steps.title: Return the phone to the cradle when you are finished with your conversation.
steps.content: Return the phone to the cradle when you are finished with your conversation.

steps.title: Remove the handset from the cradle.
steps.content: Remove the handset from the cradle. Notice the two prongs that rise from the cradle of the phone when the handset is removed. This is called the switch hook. Sometimes you will find a rotary phone that still works, but has a missing or broken dial. Pressing the switch hook is what will allow you to dial the phone despite the damage. The reason this works is because a rotary dial works by repeatedly closing the switch hook an amount of times corresponding with the number you dial. This can also be done manually by pressing the switch hook quickly. This method only works on a phone line that supports pulse dialing. Most rotary telephones, with the exception of modern clones, only work on telephone lines that support pulse dialing, so if a rotary telephone is in use or has been used before and it is not a clone, this method will work.

steps.title: Listen for a dial tone.
steps.content: Listen for a dial tone. The dial tone should be a mid-ranged, constant pitch. If you do not hear a dial tone, something is wrong. 3 Ways to Diagnose Landline Phone Problems

steps.title: Press the switch hook down to dial stop the dial tone.
steps.content: Press the switch hook down to dial stop the dial tone. Releasing the prongs should bring back the dial tone. They do not need to both be pressed, since they are mechanically connected and should move together. When you press the switch for an extended period of time, you are doing the same thing the handset would when you hang up the phone.

steps.title: Dial the first number of the phone number by pressing down on the prongs as many times as the number.
steps.content: Dial the first number of the phone number by pressing down on the prongs as many times as the number. To dial a 4 you would rapidly press the switch down four times. To dial 0, press the prongs down rapidly ten times Make sure to press the switch very quickly. Do not press it for too long, as that would register a hang-up. This process is known as switch-hook dialing.

steps.title: Pause briefly.
steps.content: Pause briefly. This is to allow a reasonable gap between digits so they are not interpreted as the same digit.

steps.title: Repeat steps four and five until you have dialed all the numbers in the phone number
steps.content: Repeat steps four and five until you have dialed all the numbers in the phone number After all the numbers are dialed, the call should automatically connect.

steps.title: Return the phone to the cradle when you are finished with your conversation.
steps.content: Return the phone to the cradle when you are finished with your conversation.
